key_points: President Donald Trump was impeached for a second time, charged with “incitement of insurrection” over the Capitol siege.
The House of Representatives voted 232-197 for impeachment, with 10 Republicans supporting the motion.
This is the most bipartisan presidential impeachment in modern times, more than Bill Clinton in 1998.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi called Trump a “clear and present danger” to the nation.
Trump, watching from the White House, released a video urging for unity and condemning the violence, without mentioning the impeachment.
The impeachment proceedings were swift, taking place just one week after the Capitol riot.
Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell signaled that Trump could face conviction in the Senate.
McConnell also sees the impeachment as a chance to reduce Trump's influence over the GOP.
Ten GOP lawmakers, including Liz Cheney, voted to impeach Trump, indicating a split in the Republican Party.
Security was exceptionally tight at the Capitol during the impeachment, with metal-detector screenings for lawmakers.
